lock.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to fasten something, usually with a key, so that other people cannot open it, or to be fastened like this
lock.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I can’t get this drawer to lock.
lock.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to put something in a place and fasten the door, lid etc with a key
lock.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Lock the cat in the kitchen.
lock.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to become fixed in one position and impossible to move, or to make something become fixed
lock.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: A moment later they were locked in an embrace  (=holding each other very tightly in a loving or friendly way).
Their eyes locked together  (=they could not look away from each other) for an instant.
He locked his hands around the younger man’s throat.
lock.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: if you are locked in a situation, you cannot get out of it
lock.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The two groups are locked in a vicious cycle of killing.
The company is locked into a five-year contract.
lock.translation[0].definitions[3].note_: Lock is usually passive in this meaning
lock.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a thing that keeps a door, drawer etc fastened and is usually opened with a key or by moving a small metal bar
lock.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I’m sorry, there isn’t a lock on the bathroom door.
The key turned stiffly in the lock.
lock.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a small number of hairs on your head that grow and hang together
lock.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: He gently pushed a lock of hair from her eyes.
lock.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a part of a canal or river that is closed off by gates so that the water level can be raised or lowered to move boats up or down a slope
lock.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a hold which wrestlers use to prevent their opponent from moving
lock.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: the degree to which a vehicle’s front wheels can be turned in order to turn the vehicle
lock.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: a playing position in the game of rugby
lock.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if two people or organizations lock horns, they start being involved in a serious disagreement or struggle with each other
lock.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Mr. Lorenzo locked horns with union representatives in his efforts to turn around the struggling business.
lock.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: if two people or organizations are locked in a battle, they are involved in a serious disagreement or struggle against each other
lock.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: The two networks are locked in a close ratings battle.
The unions are locked in difficult negotiations with the company.
lock.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to have complete control of something
lock.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The firm now has an 85% lock on the market.
Between them the two airlines have a virtual lock on domestic air traffic.
lock.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: These currency controls put a lock on Pakistan’s dealings with the larger world.
